Ben: Well, here we are in Paris, where we
launched our investigation into climate skeptics

4.text:
a few days ago. The whole thing started, actually,
I'd say, about five months ago when we were

10.text:
discussing how to bring the issue of climate
skeptics into these Paris talks, expecting

16.text:
that they would try to get a lot of publicity,
you know Lord Lawson and that kind of thing.

20.text:
We really wanted to expose them. We felt for
some time that there was a kind of market

25.text:
for climate science paid for by fossil fuel
interests and we wanted to see whether prominent

33.text:
climate skeptics would be willing to write
reports for fossil fuel interests, and whether

38.text:
they would be willing to hide that funding
from the public. So we set up a fake public

43.text:
relations company in Beirut, purporting to
represent a Middle East oil and gas company and we

47.text:
went to one individual who is very much at the
senior levels of the Global Warming Policy Foundation

53.text:
and we put this to him. We said,
'Would you write a climate skeptic report

57.text:
espousing the virtues of CO2? We're a Middle
Eastern oil company but want to keep that

61.text:
a secret from the public. Are you okay with
that?' Frankly I was surprised by how easy

66.text:
it was. He said yes. He didn't even ask
the name of this oil company.

71.text:
Interviewer: What was the next thing? Did
you actually get in contact with some scientists?

77.text:
Ben: We spoke at length with Professor Happer
via e-mail. He's the individual from Princeton,

82.text:
who's an academic advisor at the Global Warming
Policy Foundation. He then agreed to take

90.text:
the money to write the report. He knew we were
a Middle Eastern oil company. He agreed to

94.text:
keep that secret from the public. Then he
passed us through various people, who he said

99.text:
were able to help us get the money. He was
very clear that he wanted the money not to

103.text:
go to himself, but to anti-climate action
campaigners at the CO2 Coalition, where he's

109.text:
a senior member. So he wanted the money for
his report to go into that campaign group.

115.text:
The people who we spoke to, who he recommended
that we speak to, who could facilitate the

119.text:
passing over of that cash were very clear.
We told them we're a Middle Eastern oil company.

123.text:
We want to keep it secret. They said that
was absolutely no problem whatsoever. So I

127.text:
think to a certain extent our investigation
really begs the question: Down the years,

132.text:
how many other of these scientific reports
that have confused the public on climate change

137.text:
have, in fact, been paid for by oil, coal,
and gas companies without us knowing?

142.text:
I think it really matters. If you look at
a journal like science, it says that if you

146.text:
are to submit a paper to that journal, then
you have to honest about what your funding is.

152.text:
There are very good reasons for that.
We have a phrase in Britain, "He who pays

156.text:
the piper calls the tune." That is to say
if you pay for a piece of research, you can

161.text:
exert a possible subconscious effect on the
nature of the outcomes of that research. Maybe

168.text:
that's fair or unfair for these individuals,
but certainly the public deserves to know

173.text:
so they can judge for themselves. Transparency
in science is always a good thing. Transparency

178.text:
of funders is always a good thing. What we
had here were scientists willing to take money

182.text:
from fossil fuel companies and hide it from
the public.

186.text:
Interviewer: Did DonorsTrust, the topic of
that, come up in the correspondence and who are they?

190.text:
Ben: Yes, we were interested that Professor
Happer passed us up to Bill O'Keefe, who is his

196.text:
colleague at the CO2 Coalition, who runs
the George C. Marshall Institute, which is

200.text:
a very well-known climate skeptic group. O'Keefe
then passed us up the food chain to the Donors

205.text:
Trust, an organization known as the "dark-money
ATM" of the conservative movement. They are

209.text:
very good at getting money and passing it
around Conservative causes in the U.S.

214.text:
We spoke to Peter Lipsett of the DonorsTrust,
a guy very, very high up there, who used to

219.text:
be very high up in the Koch Institute, the
Charles Koch Institute, very well-known for

228.text:
spreading misinformation on climate change,
those guys. We made clear to him that we wanted

234.text:
to pass money to the CO2 Coalition in return
for Professor Happer writing this climate

241.text:
skeptic report. We said we were a Middle Eastern
oil company. We said we wanted to remain anonymous.

246.text: The DonorsTrust were absolutely fine with that.

249.text:
Interviewer: Was there any mention in the
correspondence with past examples of receiving money?

254.text:
Ben: Well, We also spoke to—or e-mailed,
I should say, Professor Frank Clemente from

259.text:
Penn State. In that case, we pretended to
be an Indonesian coal company. Clemente was

265.text:
very clear that he had been paid previously
by Peabody Coal to write research papers and

273.text:
various other things and appear as a witness,
and even to write op-eds in newspapers. On

281.text:
the latter, he definitely didn't tell his
readers that he'd been paid by coal company

287.text:
I think that's a real problem. Again, it's
one of transparency and openness. Really,

292.text:
if you're reading a piece of research, or
if you're reading a newspaper op-ed, I think

297.text:
you have a right as the public to know whether
it's being funded by someone who has an interest

301.text:
in the outcome of the climate change debate.
Fossil fuel companies constitute a small number

310.text:
of people on this planet, but a whole load
of financial clout. If they're using that

315.text:
financial clout to defend their interest against
the interests of wider society, then I think

322.text:
there's just something fundamentally undemocratic
about that actually.

325.text:
Interviewer: Last question. What role do these
kind of efforts play in the broader effort

333.text:
Ben: If you live in an English-speaking country,
America, the UK, Canada, Australia, New Zealand,

341.text:
then you are going to be familiar with the
phenomenon of organized politically-active

345.text:
climate skepticism. In the States, it's a
pretty good indicator of whether you will

351.text:
vote Republican or Democrat, your views on
climate change. It has become a really polarized

357.text:
issue. This is a big problem because we need
a societal consensus to take the kind of action

361.text:
that we need, I would argue. The climate skeptics
have done a very good job of creating doubt,

367.text:
false doubt, around the climate science, which
really narrows the political space for leaders

374.text:
So I think by pushing back on them and demonstrating
to the public that actually all is not what

379.text:
it seems here, and climate skepticism might
not be this kind of noble search for the truth

384.text:
that the skeptics proclaim themselves to be
involved in. In fact, there's a possibility

390.text:
that fossil fuel companies are using scientists
to promote their commercial prerogative. Then

397.text:
that is useful I think to push back against
this kind of false effort to distort the public

405.text:
debate and close down the political space
that our leaders have.

408.text:
Interviewer: Thanks very much, Ben. I appreciate
your time.

411.text: Ben: Cheers, mate. Thanks a lot.
